overview: From 2025-10-25 to 2025-10-26, ethereum-optimism/optimism had 2 new PRs (2 merged), 0 new issues, and 7 active contributors.

topIssues.title: Refactor super dispute game contracts to be reusable across chains
topIssues.author: mbaxter
topIssues.body:
## Description

Refactor `SuperFaultDisputeGame` and `SuperPermissionedDisputeGame` to be reusable across L2 chains.  

For more details, see [the design doc](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/design-docs/blob/main/protocol/proofs/dispute-game-creators.md) on this topic, and the work done to refactor the non-super dispute game contracts tracked in [this issue](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/12421).

topPRs.title: proofs: Migrate SuperFaultDisputeGame to creator pattern
topPRs.author: Inphi
topPRs.body:
This patch only implements the necessary OPCM functions to support the `SuperFaultDisputeGame`  for e2e testing.
Notably, `addGameType`, `updatePrestate`, and `deploy` have yet to be fully migrated to use v2 games. This is OK for the time being since we don't interact with those functions for super dispute games.

part of https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/17972

topPRs.title: chore: Stabilize & simplify docker build
topPRs.author: janjakubnanista
topPRs.body:
<!--
Contributions welcome! See https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/.github/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

**Description**

- Introduces a new `builder_foundry` build stage (built on `$TARGETPLATFORM` as opposed to `$BUILDPLATFORM`) that downloads `forge`, checks the checksum and outputs the version. Forge version could not have been checked when running this on `$BUILDPLATFORM`
- Bumps the `builder` stage image to `alpine:3.21` so that we can install the exact same `just` as we have in `mise.toml`. This in turn means we don't need to use `mise` to install it which in turn means more stable builds
- Replaces string-concatenation JSON building in `forge-checksums.sh` with a `jq`-based script

**Notes**

- Although `foundryup` is a much simpler way of installing `forge`, it would mean updating the mechanism with which we compute checksums. `curl`-based download has been preserved not to touch the `op-deployer` codebase

topPRs.title: op-node/p2p: prevent single peer failure from cancelling range sync
topPRs.author: googgoog
topPRs.body:
## Description
#10063  cancels the entire rangeRequest when any peer returns ResultCodeNotFoundErr. This forces all peers to stop working on that range and wait for the next alt-sync tick, increasing time-to-sync. In static peer setups where some peers may not yet have the requested blocks (e.g., backup sequencers or RPC nodes), a single NotFound from one peer cancels the range and unnecessarily stalls others.

## Fix
Make NotFound handling peer-local instead of global:

1. **Remove global `activeRangeRequests` tracking**: The original implementation used a global `activeRangeRequests` map to track active ranges and would delete the entire range when any peer returned NotFound, causing all peers to stop processing that range.

2. **Add peer-local `failedRanges` tracking**: Each `peerLoop` now maintains its own goroutine-local `failedRanges` map keyed by `rangeReqId`. When a peer returns NotFound for a range, we mark only that peer as failed for that range and skip subsequent blocks in that range to that specific peer.

3. **Preserve parallel syncing**: Other peers continue syncing the same range immediately without waiting for the next alt-sync tick, maximizing throughput in multi-peer setups.

This approach eliminates unnecessary global coordination, reduces memory overhead (no shared mutex-protected map), and allows healthy peers to continue syncing even when some peers don't have the requested blocks yet.
